title: Lesson 3: Rutherford's Alpha-Particle Scattering Experiment
content:
Lesson 3: Rutherford's Alpha-Particle Scattering Experiment

Putting the Plum Pudding Model to the Test

What if you shot a cannonball at a thin sheet of paper, and it bounced back?

This "impossible" scenario is exactly how scientist Ernest Rutherford described the results of his most famous experiment. He wanted to test J.J. Thomson's "Plum Pudding" model, which pictured atoms as soft, squishy spheres. Rutherford's experiment was designed to see what would happen when he fired tiny, fast "bullets" at atoms. The results were so unexpected they changed our understanding of the world forever.

The Plan: Investigating the Atom's Structure

Rutherford wanted to 'see' inside an atom. Since he couldn't use a microscope, he decided to shoot things at it. His plan was to fire fast-moving alpha (α) particles at an extremely thin sheet of gold foil. Here's what those key components were:

The "Bullets": Alpha Particles

  • Positively charged (+2).
  • Heavy and fast-moving. Think of them as tiny, powerful cannonballs.

The Target: Gold Foil

  • Chosen because it can be made incredibly thin (only about 1000 atoms thick).
  • This ensured the alpha particles would only hit a few atoms on their way through.

Rutherford surrounded the foil with a detector screen that would light up wherever an alpha particle hit it. This way, he could track the path of his tiny bullets after they passed through the foil.

What Did Rutherford Expect to Happen?

Based on Thomson's "Plum Pudding" model, the atom was a soft sphere where the positive charge and mass were spread out evenly. Therefore, Rutherford expected his heavy, powerful alpha particles to plow right through the soft gold atoms with little to no deviation. It would be like shooting a high-speed bullet through a cloud of mist—it just goes straight.

Expectation vs. "Plum Pudding" Atom

The Shocking Reality: Three Key Observations

The experiment produced results that were completely unexpected and blew away the old model. There were three distinct observations:

  1. Most of the alpha particles passed straight through the gold foil. This meant they encountered nothing in their path.
  2. Some of the alpha particles were deflected by small angles. This meant they came close to something positive that pushed them away (since the alpha particles themselves are positive).
  3. Surprisingly, one out of every 12,000 particles appeared to rebound! This meant they had hit something very dense, hard, and positively charged head-on.

The Experimental Verdict

Rutherford's gold foil experiment **disproved** the Plum Pudding model. The results just didn't match the predictions.

The shocking results left scientists with three huge clues:

Most went through

→ Hinting at empty space

Some were deflected

→ Hinting at a positive charge

Few bounced back

→ Hinting at a tiny, dense mass

These amazing observations were the puzzle pieces Rutherford needed to build a brand new, more accurate model of the atom, which we will explore in the next lesson!
questions:
Lesson 3: Questions & Answers

1. What was the main scientific goal of Rutherford's gold foil experiment? What idea was he trying to test?

The main goal was to test the validity of J.J. Thomson's "Plum Pudding" model of the atom.

Correct Answer: Rutherford was trying to test J.J. Thomson's Plum Pudding model. He wanted to see if atoms were really soft, solid spheres of positive charge with electrons embedded in them.

2. What are alpha particles, and what two properties made them perfect "bullets" for this experiment?

Alpha (α) particles are small particles released by some radioactive elements. Two properties made them ideal:

1. They are Positively Charged

This was crucial. Because they are positive, their path would be affected if they came near another positive charge (likes repel).

2. They are Heavy and Fast

Being relatively heavy and fast-moving, they were expected to easily pass through a "soft" atom without being stopped.

3. Why was it essential for Rutherford to use an extremely thin sheet of gold foil as his target?

Rutherford needed the foil to be thin for a very specific reason.

Reasoning:

He wanted the alpha particles to interact with as few atoms as possible—ideally just one. If the foil were too thick, an alpha particle might bounce around between many atoms, and the results would be confusing. A very thin foil (only ~1000 atoms thick) ensured that any deflection was caused by a collision with a single gold atom.

Thin Foil (Correct)

One interaction.

Thick Foil (Incorrect)

Confusing results.

4. Based on the Plum Pudding model, what was the expected result of the experiment? Draw the expected path of an alpha particle.

Expectation: The alpha particles should pass straight through the atoms with almost no change in their path.

Reasoning: In the Plum Pudding model, the positive charge and mass are spread out. It's like a soft mist. A heavy, fast alpha particle should easily push its way through without being deflected.

5. List the three distinct and surprising observations from Rutherford's experiment.

The three key observations were:

  1. Most alpha particles passed straight through the foil as if it were empty space.
  2. A few alpha particles were deflected by small angles, veering slightly off their original path.
  3. A very few particles (about 1 in 12,000) bounced back at very large angles, some even coming straight back towards the source.

6. What conclusion did Rutherford draw from the observation that most alpha particles went straight through the gold foil?

Conclusion: Most of the atom is empty space.

If the atoms were solid like Thomson imagined, most particles would have been blocked or deflected. The fact that they passed through untouched meant there was nothing in their way. This suggested that the atom is not a solid "pudding" but is largely empty.

7. Why did some alpha particles get deflected by small angles? What did this indicate?

This indicated that the alpha particles passed near something with a positive charge.

Explanation: Alpha particles have a positive charge. The scientific rule is that "like charges repel." When a positive alpha particle passed close to the atom's positive center, it was pushed away slightly by this repulsion force, causing it to change direction.

8. What was the most astonishing observation, and what conclusion could be drawn from it?

Most Astonishing Observation: A very small number of alpha particles (about 1 in 12,000) were deflected by large angles, essentially bouncing back.

Conclusion: There is a very small, dense, and positively charged center in the atom.

The alpha particles were too heavy and fast to be bounced back by something soft like a pudding. The only explanation was that they were hitting something incredibly tiny, but also very massive and with a strong positive charge, concentrated in one spot.

9. Did Rutherford's experiment prove the Plum Pudding model was correct or incorrect? Explain why.

Incorrect. Rutherford's experiment disproved the Plum Pudding model.

Why: The experiment's results (deflections and rebounds) directly contradicted the expected outcome. The Plum Pudding model predicted all particles would pass straight through a "soft" atom. Since they didn't, the model had to be wrong.

10. To describe his surprise, Rutherford said the result was as incredible as firing a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and having it come back and hit you. In this analogy, what does the "15-inch shell" and the "tissue paper" represent from his actual experiment?

Let's break down the analogy:

  • The "15-inch shell" (the powerful projectile): This represents the heavy and fast-moving **alpha particle**.
  • The "piece of tissue paper" (the supposedly weak target): This represents the **atom as described by the Plum Pudding model**—something that was thought to be soft and easily penetrable.

11. If the alpha particles were negatively charged instead of positively charged, how would the observation of deflection have been different?

Instead of being deflected away, they would have been attracted and pulled *towards* the positive center.

Explanation: The rule "opposites attract" would apply. A negative alpha particle would be attracted to the positive center of the atom, causing its path to curve inwards towards it, rather than being pushed outwards away from it.
exercises:
Lesson 3: Exercises

1. Fill in the Blanks

Rutherford shot positively charged ___________ particles at a thin sheet of ___________ foil. While he expected them all to pass straight through, he observed that most did, some were deflected, and a very few even ___________. This surprising result disproved Thomson's ___________ model.

  1. alpha (α)
  2. gold
  3. bounced back / rebounded
  4. Plum Pudding

2. Match the Observation to the Inference

Draw a line (mentally) to match each observation from the experiment to the conclusion Rutherford drew from it.

Observation
Inference / Conclusion
A. Most particles went straight through.
1. There is a tiny, dense, positive center.
B. A few particles were deflected.
2. The atom is mostly empty space.
C. Very few bounced back.
3. The positive center repels positive particles.
  • A → 2
  • B → 3
  • C → 1

3. What was the most surprising observation?

Out of the three main results, which one was the most unexpected and astonishing to Rutherford and his team?

The most surprising observation was that a very small fraction of alpha particles bounced back from the foil.

This was completely contrary to the Plum Pudding model and was described as being as incredible as a cannonball bouncing off tissue paper.

4. True or False?

Rutherford used gold foil because gold is a very heavy element. (True / False)

False.

While gold is heavy, the primary reason for its use was its high **malleability**. This property allowed it to be hammered into an exceptionally thin sheet, ensuring the alpha particles would interact with as few atoms as possible.

5. Predict the Path

In the diagram, an alpha particle is fired at an atom (based on Rutherford's findings). Which path (A, B, or C) would be taken by a particle that passes very close to the center?

Path B.

Path A represents a particle passing far from the center (no deflection). Path B represents a particle passing close enough to be repelled and deflected. Path C is a random path and not a realistic outcome.

6. What's the Charge?

Alpha particles have a positive charge. The part of the atom that caused some of them to deflect must have had what kind of charge?

A positive charge.

Like charges repel. The positive alpha particles were repelled (pushed away), so they must have come close to another positive charge.

7. Check your vocabulary

What does the word "scattering" mean in the context of this experiment?

"Scattering" refers to the process where the particles are deflected or spread out in various directions after colliding with or passing near the atoms in the target. It's the opposite of them all staying in one straight beam.

8. Model vs. Reality

The "Plum Pudding" model suggested the positive charge of an atom was...

  1. Concentrated in the center.
  2. Spread out uniformly.
  3. Located on the outside of the atom.

The experimental results suggested it was...

The "Plum Pudding" model suggested the positive charge was B. Spread out uniformly.

The experimental results suggested it was A. Concentrated in the center.

9. Correct the Analogy

A student compares the gold foil experiment to throwing sand at a brick wall. Why is this analogy incorrect? What's a better one?

This analogy is incorrect because the sand (light projectile) would all bounce off the brick wall (solid target). In Rutherford's experiment, the projectiles were heavy and the target was thought to be soft.

A better analogy is Rutherford's own: firing a cannonball (heavy projectile) at a sheet of tissue paper (supposedly soft target).

10. Find the Odd One Out

Which of the following was NOT a part of Rutherford's experimental setup?
Gold Foil, Alpha Particles, Detector Screen, Negative Plate

Odd one out: Negative Plate.

The experiment did not require electric plates to guide the particles; it only observed how they scattered after hitting the foil.

11. What If?

What if ALL the alpha particles had passed straight through the foil without any deflection? What would Rutherford have concluded?

If all particles had passed straight through, it would have **confirmed** J.J. Thomson's Plum Pudding model. It would have meant the atom really was a soft sphere with no hard, dense center to deflect the particles.

12. Two Truths and a Lie

Which statement about the alpha scattering experiment is the LIE?

  1. Alpha particles are positively charged.
  2. The experiment proved that atoms are mostly empty space.
  3. About half of the alpha particles bounced back.

The lie is C.

Only a very, very small fraction (1 in 12,000) of particles bounced back. If half had bounced back, it would mean the atom was mostly a solid, dense object, not mostly empty space.

13. Visual Clue

This diagram shows one alpha particle (A) passing far from the center, and one (B) hitting it head-on. Which path corresponds to the most common observation, and which to the rarest?

  • Most Common: Path A (passing straight through).
  • Rarest: Path B (rebounding back).

14. Fill in the Adjectives

Based on the experimental results, Rutherford concluded that the positive center of an atom must be very _ _ _ _ _ and very _ _ _ _ _.

Small and Dense

It had to be small because so few particles hit it. It had to be dense (massive) to make the heavy alpha particles bounce off.

15. The Final Word

Did Rutherford's experiment tell us where the electrons were in the atom?

No, it did not.

The main focus and conclusion of the scattering experiment was about the positive charge and the mass. The alpha particles were too heavy to be affected by the tiny electrons, so the experiment gave no information on their location or behavior. Figuring that out was the next challenge!
intros:
Lesson 3: Rutherford's Alpha-Particle Scattering Experiment

The groundbreaking experiment that shot down the Plum Pudding model and revealed the atom's shocking secret.

Intro 1: The Tissue Paper Cannonball

What if you fired a cannonball at a sheet of tissue paper, and it bounced back at you?

Ernest Rutherford described his experiment with this exact analogy. He was testing the "Plum Pudding" model, which pictured the atom as a soft, squishy sphere. To test it, he fired tiny, fast, and heavy "bullets" called alpha particles at a super-thin sheet of gold foil—which should have been like shooting cannonballs through tissue paper.

He expected all the alpha particles to fly straight through. But to his complete astonishment, some of them bounced off! This was as "incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you." This impossible result meant the "Plum Pudding" model was wrong, and the atom held a shocking secret.

The "impossible" result that changed our view of the atom forever.

Intro 2: The Ghost Wall

Imagine throwing tennis balls at a wall, but almost all of them go straight through it! What does that tell you about the wall?

Rutherford's experiment was like this. He expected his tiny "tennis balls" (alpha particles) to be stopped by the gold foil "wall." But the vast majority flew through as if the wall wasn't even there! This immediately told him that Thomson's idea of a solid, "pudding-like" atom was wrong.

The only way the particles could pass through was if the atoms making up the gold foil were mostly empty space. But what about the few that bounced back? They must have hit something incredibly small, hard, and dense inside that "empty" atom. The ghost wall had a few solid bricks hidden inside it!

Discovering that atoms are mostly empty, like ghost walls.

Intro 3: Probing the Pudding

How do you test a scientific idea? You poke it and see what happens!

Scientific ideas aren't accepted just because they sound good. They must be tested. After Thomson proposed his "Plum Pudding" model, Ernest Rutherford designed an experiment to test it—to literally poke the pudding and see what it was made of. His "poking sticks" were alpha particles, which were fast, heavy, and positively charged.

According to Thomson's model, the atom was soft and its positive charge was spread out. Therefore, the alpha particles should have easily pushed through, maybe wobbling a tiny bit but never bouncing back. The fact that some bounced back dramatically meant that the positive charge in an atom wasn't a soft pudding at all—it was something much smaller and more powerful.

Poking the pudding and finding a solid pit inside!

Intro 4: A Game of Marbles

You roll a marble into a big patch of soft sand. What do you expect to happen? What if it hits something hard?

Thomson's Plum Pudding model was like a giant patch of soft sand. Rutherford's experiment involved rolling tiny, heavy marbles (alpha particles) into it. He logically expected the marbles to just keep rolling in a straight line, maybe slowing down a little. For the most part, he was right! Most particles did go straight through.

But the incredible part was that once in a while, a marble would hit something and fly off in a completely different direction, sometimes even straight back! This could only mean one thing: hidden within the vast "sand pit" of the atom, there had to be a tiny, super-hard "rock" that the marbles were occasionally hitting.

Finding the hidden rock in a field of sand.

Intro 5: The Unexpected Result

In science, when an experiment gives you the exact opposite of what you expected, what does it mean?

It means your initial idea is probably wrong! Rutherford and his team fully expected their alpha particles to pass through the gold atoms of the foil with almost no change in direction, based on Thomson's model. This was their "hypothesis" or prediction.

When the experimental results showed something completely different—with some particles being wildly deflected—it delivered a major shock. It proved that the prediction, and therefore the Plum Pudding model it was based on, was incorrect. The unexpected result was not a failure; it was a huge breakthrough that forced scientists to completely rethink the structure of the atom.

When a "wrong" result leads to the right answer.
summary:
Lesson 3: Summary

Rutherford's Alpha-Particle Scattering Experiment

Objective: To test J.J. Thomson's atomic model and understand the arrangement of sub-atomic particles within an atom. Ernest Rutherford designed this landmark experiment to probe the atom's internal structure.

The Experimental Setup

Target: Thin Gold Foil

A very thin sheet of gold (only about 1000 atoms thick) was chosen because gold is highly malleable.

Projectiles: Alpha (α) Particles

These are fast-moving, positively charged particles (doubly-charged Helium ions, He²⁺) with considerable mass (4u) and energy.

Visualizing the Experiment and its Results

Expectations vs. Reality: The Key Observations

Expected Outcome (based on Thomson's model)

Since the positive charge was thought to be spread out, it was expected that all α-particles would pass through with only very minor deflections. Large deflections were not anticipated.

Actual Observations (The reality)

  • ✓Most particles passed straight through, undeflected.
  • !A few particles were deflected by small angles.
  • !!A very small fraction (1 in 12,000) rebounded, deflecting by almost 180°.

"It was almost as incredible as if you fire a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it comes back and hits you."

— Ernest Rutherford, on the unexpected results
